title: 103_hr2328
content: The "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congressional findings and purpose are outlined in the Act. The Congress finds that utilizing young men and women in a Public Lands Corps can benefit them by providing education and work opportunities, enhancing their understanding of natural resources, and helping them pay for higher education. This also benefits the nation's economy and environment. The Public Lands Corps aims to address the disrepair and degradation of facilities and natural resources on public lands and Indian reservations through labor-intensive rehabilitation and restoration work. Youth conservation corps have a proven track record of cost-effective and efficient maintenance of these resources, especially when working in partnership with government land management agencies. The Public Lands Corps aims to perform conservation, rehabilitation, restoration, and improvement work on public lands and Indian lands in a cost-effective manner. It also aims to expose young individuals to public service and educate them about natural and cultural resources. The Public Lands Corps aims to expose young individuals to conservation careers and stimulate interest in conservation professions among the nation's youth. It also seeks to expand educational opportunities for participants in national service by providing increased access to higher education or job training. The Public Lands Corps aims to expose young individuals to conservation careers and stimulate interest in conservation professions among the nation's youth. It also seeks to expand educational opportunities for participants in national service by providing increased access to higher education or job training. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines the terms "Corps" as the Public Lands Corps, "public lands" as lands owned or administered by the United States, and "qualified youth or conservation corps" as programs offering full-time work for individuals aged 16 to 25. The Public Lands Corps offers productive work for individuals aged 16 to 25 in natural or cultural resource settings, providing a mix of work experience, skills, education, and training. Participants also have the opportunity to develop citizenship values and skills through community service. The term "Indian tribe" includes any group recognized as such by the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Indian" refers to a person who is a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" include real property owned by Indian tribes or held in trust by the United States. The term "State" includes various regions within the United States. A "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" refers to efforts focused on preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources. The Public Lands Corps Program is established. Establishment of Public Lands Corps for young men and women aged 16-25 by the Department of the Interior and Agriculture. Participants must be U.S. citizens or residents, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and not have dropped out of school. The Public Lands Corps is established for young individuals aged 16-25 by the Department of the Interior and Agriculture. Participants must be U.S. citizens or residents with a high school diploma or equivalent, and not have dropped out of school. The Corps can enter into contracts with qualified youth or conservation corps for project implementation. The Secretary of Agriculture can use the Public Lands Corps or qualified youth/conservation corps for conservation projects on public or Indian lands. Preference is given to projects with long-term public benefits, instilling work ethic, being labor-intensive, and prompt initiation. The Public Lands Corps or qualified youth/conservation corps can be used for conservation projects on public or Indian lands. Projects should be labor-intensive, have prompt initiation, and provide educational opportunities. Projects must be consistent with laws and policies governing the area. Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can provide quarters for conservation centers. The Secretaries of Agriculture and Interior are authorized to provide necessary services, facilities, and equipment for conservation programs, including establishing and using conservation centers. They may also arrange logistical support from the Secretary of Defense, including temporary tent shelters, transportation, and residential supervision near conservation centers. The Secretaries of Agriculture and Interior establish health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety standards for conservation centers. They can contract with state, local, and private organizations for center management. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. Authorization for qualified college students or recent graduates to be placed in Federal land managing agencies as resource assistants without regard to civil service laws. Participants will be recruited from colleges and universities. The Resource Assistant Program recruits college students and recent graduates from diverse backgrounds to work in Federal land managing agencies. The program aims to increase workforce diversity and provide participants with exposure to potential career opportunities in conservation agencies. Existing nonprofit organizations can implement the program to provide career exposure in conservation agencies. Participating organizations must fund 25% of the interns' expenses through private sources. Nonprofit conservation service organizations participating in the Resource Assistant program must fund 25% of the total costs for each recruited participant. They are required to submit an annual report evaluating the program's scope, size, and quality, including the value of work contributed by the Resource Assistants to the agency's mission. SEC. 6. Living allowances and terms of service for participants. Living allowances are provided to participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants under a program established by the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture. The living allowance should not exceed the maximum established for participants in the national service program. Participants agree to a term of service determined by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program receive living allowances based on terms of service set by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture, similar to the national service program. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program receive educational benefits or awards. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program are eligible for national service awards under the National and Community Service Act of 1990 if they meet the program requirements set by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture. The benefits and awards' usage period, purposes, and amounts are determined under the Act's guidelines. For borrowers in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program, lenders must grant forbearance on Stafford Loans upon request, in line with regulations. Borrowers serving in these programs and eligible for post-service educational benefits can receive forbearance. SEC. 8. NONDISPLACEMENT. The nondisplacement requirements of the National and Community Service Act of 1990 apply to all activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps under this Act. SEC. 9. FUNDING. Cost Sharing: The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can pay up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps. The remaining 25% can come from nonfederal sources. No cost sharing is required for projects on Indian lands. The Public Lands Corps, established under this Act, can receive contributions from a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency for project costs. No cost sharing is required for projects on Indian lands. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture are eligible to receive funds for programs under the National and Community Service Act. Agriculture is eligible to receive funds under the National and Community Service Act of 1990 without restrictions. Authorization of appropriations is provided as necessary to carry out this Act.
